segments.text: Well I was very pleased when everything checked out and got in the maneuvering unit.
It checked out and I was able to go ahead and start flying it around.
Was it fun?
Yeah it was fun.
Your newspaper article said that you had a great deal of fun with it and that your wife Bernadette said that you didn't want to come in again.
Well it flew very much like the simulator so that
I was able to relax and enjoy flying the thing.
It was a pleasure to be in an environment where there were no artificial limits to the number of degrees of roll, pitch, or yaw you could go through.
You didn't have to worry about encumbering cables or umbilicals or things of that sort.
Basically, it was just a matter of getting on with the planned profile
out the system and making sure that indeed it flew as it appeared to.
When was the project for the MMU first brought to your attention?
Well, actually, the Air Force built a maneuvering unit known as the Astronaut Maneuvering Unit, which was carried on Gemini 9, which flew in June of 1967.
if I recall correctly.

And one of the, or the fatal, if I can call it that, problem there was that the pressure-shoot technology was in such an infant state that Gene Cernan, who was to fly it, became exhausted and overheated and things of that sort before he could do so.
There were some problems with that unit as well, but it had been scheduled to fly again on Gemini 12 and was taken off because our
confidence in EVA technology was on sort of a roller coaster cycle.
That is, Gemini 9 had problems.
10 went well.
11 had problems.
They figured that they would finish up the Gemini program on a positive note.
So they made the spacewalk on Gemini 12 a very simple one.
So maneuvering units were in low regard, I guess you could say.
at that time.
An Air Force captain by the name of Ed Whitsitt had an idea for an experiment inside the Skylab workshop, which was then being talked about as Apollo Applications AAP.
And I got together with him.
And over the course of a few years, we put together an experiment, which came to be known as M509, or the Astronaut Maneuvering Research Vehicle, which was an experimental maneuvering unit.

that was in fact carried inside the Skylab workshop and flown inside the workshop in a pressurized environment so that you got the zero-gravity maneuvering dynamics, but it didn't have to be qualified for vacuum or for the thermal extremes of space or for the reliability.
Five Skylab crewmen flew it for a total of about 14 flying hours, and we took the data
from that experiment and the in-flight films and TV footage and used them to sell the MMU for the shuttle program.
So I guess you could say the whole thing stretched from about the fall of 1967 on up to the spring of 1984.
The MMU is viewed as a technological breakthrough in space travel.
Are there plans underway for a larger space vehicle based on the same propulsion system?
Well, we'd like to roughly double the propellant supply in the MMU to shift it over to a microprocessor-based control system.
Those are about the only things that we see on the immediate horizon.
Now, there have been some
concepts around for a number of years for something they call a personnel transporter, which would be the orbital analog of a motor scooter.
You could climb aboard the thing, and it would probably look a lot like a stand-up motor scooter, but with a larger platform out behind it, so you could carry two and maybe three
There's also been a proposal known as the Man Remote Workstation, which is a little enclosed capsule with manipulator arms sticking out the front of propulsion jets and things like that on it.
very similar to the little capsule in 2001 in Space Odyssey.
But again, that hasn't gotten beyond the artist concept stage.
But one of the things that's being done with the space station program is to put about 10% of our development funding, at least initially, into looking at
automation and robotics and what that could do for the system, it may be that something like this would fall out of it.
How did you go about testing it in preparation for the flight, and did you use a simulator as you earlier said, and how fast were you traveling when you were using MMU in space?
Okay, let's take the questions one at a time.
Okay.
As far as the speed in space, both I
And the orbiter were moving along at about 17,000 miles an hour, which is the orbital velocity at our altitude of about 150 nautical miles.
The relative speed between myself and the MMU and the orbiter was never more than about 1.5 to 2 feet per second.
The idea is basically you're maneuvering with respect to the orbiter much as you fly formation between two airplanes.
Small, deliberate movements or control inputs, and you wait for the effect of these velocity changes to take effect.
And then you put in another one, and you wait for it to take effect.
So I was actually moving rather slowly with respect to the orbiter and fast with respect to the Earth.

As far as simulating and testing the MMU goes, a lot of our development work, both for the M509 unit in Skylab and for the MMU and training, was done on a large six degree of freedom moving base simulator at the Martin Marietta Aerospace Company outside of Denver.
This device has a track and a large room, about 60 feet long,
And a carriage can move up and down this track.
And then on top of the carriage, which is about 17 feet wide, is another set of tracks, which enable a tower that's about 15 or 20 feet tall to move back and forth.
So you can move anywhere in the room.
And then on this tower, projecting out from the side of it, able to move up and down, is a gimbal head that can be driven in roll, pitch, and yaw.

have a machine that's man-rated so you can put people in it and build a portion of the MMU crew station that controls and displays into this so you can climb in and by inputting the electrical signals from the hand controllers to a computer and running that into a servo system you can cause the thing to behave as though it were in a weightless environment and in fact as though the laws of
orbital mechanics were being obeyed and things of that sort so that we get a very realistic simulation.

We also designed it so that you can input intentional malfunctions modeled after the system failure modes so that you can cause a thruster to appear to stick on or a battery to fail and things of that sort and require the pilot to take the appropriate corrective action to recover from it and keep flying.
By way of explanation, the MMU for orbiter applications was designed to be totally redundant.
That is, we had 24 little compressed nitrogen thrusters split into two systems of 12 each, either one of which was adequate for flying around and controlling the shell.
So while we normally used

combination of 24 it's sort of like having an orchestra where you can split the thing in half if you do it right and still still play music each system had its own battery and its own propellant tank and its own control logic and its own set of switches and the hand controls so most of the malfunction recovery consisted of identifying the system in which the failure had occurred and shutting the bad system off and continuing with what was left

By way of testing, before I get off the training aspect, one of the other things that we do is use a weightless simulation derived from a water tank where you get in a pressure suit and there's a certain amount of air trapped inside it because you pressurized it three and a half or four pounds per square inch over the water pressure.
And this makes you buoyant.
So you add lead weights until you are
neutrally buoyant or displacing as much water as you weigh.
And then you can maneuver slowly, hand over hand, and take different attitudes as though you were weightless.
So we built an MMU that was ballasted out to be neutrally buoyant as well, and we have a mock-up of the orbiter cargo bay in our water tank, and we developed

flight support station, which is the thing that holds the MMU and the orbiter, and also the procedures for getting into it and getting out of it and getting it out of the flight support station and back in at the end of the mission so you could bring it home using the water tank.
And this was a lot of effort put into that since one of the problems back in the Gemini program had been the difficulty of getting into the astronaut maneuvering unit
And that contributed to Gene Surin's problems with overheating and fatigue.
The fact that that worked very well on orbit also indicates that we did the job right.
Testing took a number of different forms.
We, of course, tested each of the components at the component level, pressure regulators, electronics, control units, things of that sort.
And additionally, the MMU and the flight support station

subjected to extreme cold and extreme high temperature runs in vacuum to verify that none of the components were going to fail at high temperatures or that you wouldn't have lubricants that congeal at low temperatures or differential thermal expansion and contraction of metallic parts that would bind up.
And in fact, we came up with a few little problems each time which were corrected.
Then shortly before the mission, that is about
Last October, we had two manned thermal vacuum chamber runs down here at the Johnson Space Center where I ran one of them, and I think Pinky Nelson ran the other one.
And we got in pressure suits into this large vacuum chamber about 30 feet in diameter and maybe 50 feet high.

which was pumped down to probably something less than 10 to the minus 5 or 10 to the minus 6 torr, and had walls cooled with liquid nitrogen and a solar simulator being a bank of arc lights so that we could subject the MNU to these streams of temperature as well in there.
And then we went in and manually operated them and fired the thrusters and cycled everything to verify that it worked.
And in fact, in that context, we also
came up with an electrical problem in the MNUs that, had it not been corrected, had the potential of making them inoperable in orbit.
And that was fixed.
And it looks like we finally got all of the bugs out of the thing before the mission, which was what we had set out to do.
At the same time, let me mention that the folks at Martin, the contractor,
built in and who were particularly anxious as well to have a successful mission because they felt like a lot of their corporate pride was resting on it.
And they really bent over backwards and did everything that they could to make it work.
And they did.
It worked very well.
Astronaut Alan Bean said in an interview done by an A&M student that his family and marriage were severely impacted by his career.
Do you think your family has been impacted by your career?
And in so what way?
Well, we came to Texas quite a while ago, and we seem to have survived coming to Texas.
I don't think it has really been impacted.
I've put a lot of work into the program, but seems happy around here.
She has horses.
Bruce and Tracy have grown up here locally and gone to UT.
And, in fact, Bruce just finished a year at the University of Reading in England, got back toward the end of the summer.
So I think we're working on it very well.
Good, good.
You are the newest McCandless to make significant US history, with your father and both grandfathers being outstanding naval men.
How do you feel about carrying on this legacy, and does your son continue
want to continue in his tradition?
Well, Bruce is interested, apparently, in the Foreign Service or perhaps the law career, as opposed to a naval career, and that's certainly his option.
I would be the last person to try to force him into something like that.
One of my memories from the Naval Academy was how unhappy
those individuals were that had been forced into the Naval Academy because Daddy was an admiral and such and such, or Daddy wanted to do this, that, or the other.
So it's been strictly his call.
I'm very pleased to have been carrying on the Naval tradition, although in all candor, what I have been doing down here at NASA for the last several years is really fairly far removed
driving the ship around on the surface of the ocean or flying an airplane off a carrier.
It is a different sort of an ocean, if I can use that analogy.
And of course, it's also one that the Navy is currently very interested in.
With all of the land spaceflight programs, and most particularly the space shuttle program, we've had Earth observations.
Let me call it an experiment or an experimental program, basically.

It started out back in the Gemini program with the guys taking pictures out the window and saying, gee whiz, look at that, and has evolved from there to the point where each shuttle flight has a number of cameras on board and we try to take observations of significant oceanographic and land-based phenomena.
I'm not talking about pictures of
or things like that, because we don't get that detail.
But we're looking at volcanic activity, land use patterns, ocean currents, eddies, swirls, waves, and things of that sort.

And the Navy has been so interested in that that on the last flight, in fact, we had a civilian naval oceanographer, Paul Skelly Powers, who was sponsored by the oceanographer of the Navy aboard the shuttle flight, to go up there personally and make some observations and take pictures.
So the Navy is very interested.
They're also interested in how the Navy can use the space station if, in fact, the space station comes to pass.
I put it that way because the official position of the Defense Department is that they aren't interested because they don't have any money they want to put into it.
But if the space station is going to be up there, the Navy, at least, would like to be there using it to observe the oceans and gather data along those lines.
Has the selection process for NASA astronauts changed since you were first selected?
And if there is a change, is it due to the inclusion of women?
Well, no, the selection process has changed.
First off, we have gotten away from the concept that everybody has to be a pilot.

When I came in, I came in as a pilot astronaut, of course, but at the same time, the scientist astronauts that were in the group before and the group after me all went through a flight training to become pilots.
The current mission specialist selectees need not be pilots, and if they aren't pilots, why they don't get trained as pilots?
The criteria for selecting pilot astronauts is still about the same as when I came in,
maybe a little bit more relaxed since we need more people.

But as far as physical qualifications go, in the early days, there was this tremendous emphasis on picking the few individuals that could withstand the physical rigors of space flight and things of that sort.
When the shuttle was designed, it was intentionally built so that the vast majority of people that were walking around under their own power would be physically qualified.
So we've been able to greatly relieve the physical qualifications.

In the mission specialist arena, we're still looking for people with advanced degrees in engineering, science, or medical degrees, reasonable physical health, and that are interested in space careers.
That's a lot less stringent than some of the previous criteria.

interesting shift is that the first group of scientists astronauts that were selected in 1965 were selected based on their already existing preeminence in scientific fields the trend in recent years seems to be to pick people who have the educational background but who are just out of school or perhaps in their late 20s and have a lot of potential but haven't necessarily
and gotten themselves all wrapped up in various scientific institutions.
And of course, it's been broadened to include women.
And with the payload specialists, NASA doesn't really have any criteria that I am aware of for the payload specialists, other than the fact that they be sponsored by their government or company.
and that we get the right of refusal if they appear to be unsuited for space flight.
How do you view NASA's future, and are there any new plans underway for exploration to other planets, or maybe a Mars mission as you mentioned earlier?
Well, NASA first is a research and development agency.

The agency has surprised itself, I think would be a fair statement, by finding that having built the space shuttle, it's now obligated to operate it, as opposed to just building one and saying, gee, it worked.
So there's a little bit of transition and progress there in learning to operate it, and to operate it economically and reliably, by reliably I mean on a timetable or schedule.

I wouldn't be at all surprised to see in a few years that the whole shuttle program is spun off into some sort of governmental, quasi-governmental corporation, somewhat like the ComSat Corporation operates, or potentially even bought out completely by some sort of team composed of aerospace industry and airline transport.
There have been a number of nibbles along those lines, but nobody has yet come up with all the money required.
There was also a realization that the space shuttle, although it's neat right now, is not the ultimate space vehicle.
And if you look at ships and airplanes, it was opined that a 25-year lifetime was probably a reasonable lifetime for the space shuttle vehicle
as a technologically viable entity.
And this meant that about the year 2005, there better be something else getting ready to fly, or we'd be in the dinosaur age, so to speak.
And aerospace projects seem to take about seven, eight, 10 years to go from inception to completion.
So between now and 95 appeared to be a sort of a window that something
could be done in the meantime, or in which something could be done.
And this was one of the reasons advanced for doing the space station now is to build a space station in this window before starting to work on a shuttle replacement.
At the same time, though, there is a considerable movement building strength to develop a lunar base in the early 2000s or the early 20s.
perhaps followed by a Mars mission or something of that sort.

But all you can say right now is that there was last week a meeting in Washington that was attended by a lot of former astronauts and a lot of space technology figures, some science fiction writers, and the current NASA administrator, Mr. Webb, and people like that.
I said Webb, I meant Beggs.
They were both Jim, Jim Webb and Jim Beggs.
The current NASA administrator, Jim Beggs, and he supported a future Mars lunar mission.
But I've got to point out to you that right now there is no money in the budget for anything like that.
The only planetary mission that NASA has right now, budgeted,
is the Galileo probe to Jupiter, which was scheduled to be launched in 86 from the shuttle, I believe.
And presumably, it would get to Jupiter about three years later, put a probe down through the atmosphere, unmanned, of course, to see if there is a surface or see what's below the atmosphere.
So I think eventually, there probably will be some sort of return to the moon
or go for Mars, and of course this Jerry Neal space colony thing is a potential way of doing it, but right now it's still quite a ways in the future.
The famous words of Neil Armstrong as he first walked on the moon have become a household phrase.
If you had the chance to give a phrase to history, what would it be?
Well, I took Neil's words and paraphrased them.

I was the Capcom during Apollo 11 when Neil came back with his words, after having assured me pre-launch that he had nothing prepared and no words in mind, and he was just going to say something like, oh heck, here we are.
You were the voice at the Apollo mission, weren't you, from that, from Houston?
Right.
Yes, I remember that.
So I just put these words on the MMU plate, twisted them around a little bit.
I'm not really in the business of leaving phrases for history.
Have you really enjoyed your career?
Has it been something that you've never regretted and known is the way you'd like to go?
Oh, this is a thing that's interested me since, oh, probably the early 40s.

My grandfather, Bradley, discouraged me at the time after I had gotten a book on space travel, saying that, yeah, it probably happened, but not in this century, and I should concentrate on more worthwhile things like command of a battleship or an aircraft carrier or something like that.
And, of course, things just came along a lot more rapidly.
The space program has always been very interesting down here.
There's never a dull moment.
So I don't regret any of it.
Your sisters, Rosemary and Sue, both did an interview that you grew up looking at the moon.
And Rosemary even went so far as to say that she was sure that she had danced on the rooftops one Christmas to convince her that there were reindeer there.
No, they just said that you have been very interested in space since you were very young.
I have been interested in space, but I've also been interested in science and technology in general.
Electronics, finance, chemistry, things of that sort.
Well, that's about all I have.
Okay, well.
I appreciate it.
Thank you.
I do want to ask you...
I think Bruce has some tuna sandwiches or something.
Ask the question, hey, are all birth defects inherited?
Or is it a possibility that in utero, certain things in the environment will cause birth defects?
Well, what we have to look at is a combination of events that transpire.
Yes, there are selected types of birth defects that are hereditary.
And then there are those that are classed as non-hereditary.
And so that's what we want to kind of gear to now and focus on are some of the aspects of birth defect.
If you will now, please use the fast forward switch, run this tape out, and go to tape two, and we will look at some of those aspects of birth defects.
Please do that now.
